qas.question: What microorganism can notably absorb a very high concentrate of uranium?
What lichen is known to absorb a uranium concentration nearly 300 times higher than the amount in the environment?
What is given to Citrobacter to cause it to absorb uranyl ions?
What protobacterium notably bioremediates ground water uranium?
What fungus is known to cause uranium content in its symbiotic plant roots to increase?
What macroorganism can notably absorb a very high concentrate of uranium?
What lichen is known to absorb a uranium concentration nearly 400 times higher than the amount in the environment?
What is taken from Citrobacter to cause it to absorb uranyl ions?
What protobacterium never bioremediates ground water uranium?
What fungus is known to cause uranium content in its symbiotic plant roots to decrease?

context: Some organisms, such as the lichen <a1_0><b6_0>Trapelia involuta<b6_0/><a1_0/> or microorganisms such as the bacterium <a0_0><b5_0>Citrobacter<b5_0/><a0_0/>, can absorb concentrations of uranium that are up to 300 times the level of their environment. Citrobacter species absorb uranyl ions when given <a2_0><b7_0>glycerol phosphate<b7_0/><a2_0/> (or other similar organic phosphates). After one day, one gram of bacteria can encrust themselves with nine grams of uranyl phosphate crystals; this creates the possibility that these organisms could be used in bioremediation to decontaminate uranium-polluted water. The proteobacterium <a3_0><b8_0>Geobacter<b8_0/><a3_0/> has also been shown to bioremediate uranium in ground water. The mycorrhizal fungus <a4_0><b9_0>Glomus intraradices<b9_0/><a4_0/> increases uranium content in the roots of its symbiotic plant.
